domainsSkills.domainDescription: The ability to write high-quality code that is easy to understand, maintain and change. It involves a strong understanding of programming languages and practices, as well as the ability to apply this knowledge to solve problems efficiently. Included in this skill is also the ability to proficiently read code.

level1Skills.text: Produces working code that is simple, readable and maintainable
Demonstrates through code a solid understanding of the features of the team’s commonly used language(s) or platform
Demonstrates through code a solid understanding of data store modelling and query writing
Demonstrates through code a solid understanding of end-user design (e.g. UI/UX, APIs, tooling)
Adhere’s to the explicitly and implicitly defined code patterns of a codebase
Defaults to using existing code patterns and conventions over creating new ones
Avoids over-engineering; implements only the required functionality; YAGNI; Worse is Better
Identifies and elegantly handles edge cases
Proficient with developer tools (e.g. IDE, editor, command line)

level3Skills.text: Structures code so it can be easily changed and tested without negatively impacting readability
Refrains from DRYing code until the proper abstraction emerges
Well versed in advanced data store features, while only employing them when needed
Codes confidently, comprehending the cause of both existing behaviour and their modifications to it
Quickly ramps up on technology new to them (e.g. languages, databases, event streams, cloud services)
Produces code that scales, in terms of performance, to long-term workloads and data volumes
Incorporates new abstractions and patterns (when needed) through prototypes and gaining team buy-in
Enhances the security profile of a codebase via code changes in order to mitigate security risks

level5Skills.text: Has a track record across engineering of writing resilient code that is bug-free and disruption-free
Effortlessly produces working prototypes for developers who are stuck on complex coding problems
Capable of meaningful contributions to convoluted framework, library, or language code within days of exposure
Inspires the organization to improve their ability to learn and contribute to unfamiliar codebases
Wrote or heavily contributed to a programming language

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The ability to assess and provide feedback on the quality and functionality of code. It is demonstrated during formal code review and informal knowledge sharing.

level1Skills.text: Respectful with all comments in pull requests and technical documents
Enables developers to review their code through good pull request hygiene (e.g. well-scoped pull request, logical commits, good pull request description)
Responsive when addressing feedback provided in pull requests
Ensures all identified acceptance criteria has been met before requesting initial reviews
Ensures all identified acceptance criteria has been met when reviewing code
Demonstrates an effort to provide code review feedback over providing blind approvals
Provides constructive and clear feedback when reviewing code
Treats tests as first-class citizens during code review to ensure readability and that there are no gaps
Highlights code that strays from codebase conventions during code review
Proficient with version control tools (e.g. branch management)

level3Skills.text: Quick to review and re-review code and technical documents
Identifies and raises overlooked edge cases, constraints and limitations (e.g. technical, regulatory) during code review
Identifies performance issues in pull requests and technical documents (e.g. missing database index, excessive calls to a service, execution on main vs background thread)
Provides constructive code reviews by including relevant links, examples of alternate solutions and code suggestions
Enforces secure coding practices (e.g. OWASP, promptly patching security vulnerabilities) by providing relevant information and feedback
Reduces the amount of questions asked in code reviews by getting answers themselves (e.g. running pull requests locally) and sharing the answers
Proactively communicates team feedback and requirements to code owners
Reduces recurring code review comments by automating or documenting them away
Contributes to code not directly in the scope of the team via both code review and code contributions

level5Skills.text: A paragon and innovator in regards to enabling developers to review the code they authored (e.g. preparatory pull requests, explanations of technical concepts)
Masterfully mediates disagreements on technical decisions using the trust and respect the parties have for the individual
Promotes a culture of proactive code sharing across the organization to maximize the benefits for all teams
Fosters a culture of rigorous security examination of code and architecture changes as a way of promoting the prevention of vulnerabilities
Considerably reduces the time spent reviewing code in the company without impacting code quality by championing cutting-edge processes, or technology such as AI

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The practice of maintaining code throughout its lifecycle, ensuring it is reliable and secure. Aspects of code stewardship can be seen in code review, testing, CI/CD processes and documentation.

level1Skills.text: Identities and drives the work for updating dependencies
Ensures all their code changes include clearly readable and maintainable code and also include Class/File comments, function comments and logic comments when necessary.

Ensures code changes don’t decrease the quality of the codebase or impact the developer experience for other team members (e.g. increasing test or CI runtimes, build times) and optimize them when necessary.
Writes or maintains the onboarding material (e.g. Confluence, OpsLevel, README) for their codebase or the feature they have worked on
Actively identifies performance issues or tech debt and communicates these items to a broader audience
Refactors existing code that is inconsistent with the patterns of the codebase
Ensuring codebase meets eng-wide standards (e.g. passing OpsLevel checks, proactively implementing standards that were discussed eng-wide)

level3Skills.text: Participates in internal knowledge sharing sessions related to development (e.g. demo days, lunch & learns, etc.)
Aware of and proactively incorporates new language, library and framework features soon after they are released
Ensures everyone’s contributions to codebases do not unnecessarily increase build, startup and execution/run times
Leads refactors of their team's existing code that is inconsistent with the patterns of the codebase, code standards or to better leverage new design patterns
Responsibly leads investigations on adding a new dependency by evaluating the need for it, alternate options, licenses, testing and documentation, all while while keeping teams informed
Leads the investigation for the need of new dependency when needed through thorough investigation POC, learning sessions for teams a
Leads both code and test dependency updates that requires major refactors across the codebase to adopt latest versions
Helps define and maintain standards around coding practices across all teams
Takes initiative to champion out-of-scope tech debt work surfaced in pull requests

level5Skills.text: Actively coaches/mentors developers on other teams about maintaining code and ensuring standards are actively followed

Builds and maintains tools/processes that enforce consistency across the organization which helps reduce the feedback cycle and increase/improves velocity across teams (related to OpsLevel, linters, CI, etc.)
Participates and presents in conference talks on code stewardship
Helps maintain and contribute to Open Source Software we are heavily dependent on (e.g. Apollo)
Wrote or heavily contributed to a well-known tool in the industry which enforce and educate on best practices.

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The ability to design, articulate, evaluate and implement system and code architecture practices that improves various elements of the system and meets business objectives.

level1Skills.text: Demonstrates awareness of commonly known failure patterns (e.g. N+1 query problem, missing db indexes, race conditions)
Knows when to use common coding patterns (e.g. SOLID principles, MVC/MVVC/MVVM design approaches, factory, observer)
Stays informed on and implements language best practices and tooling (e.g. linters, static code analyzers)
Identifies gaps or limitations in the existing code/system architecture
Builds solutions with system, resource, or device constraints in mind (e.g. CPU, memory, disk, network)
Makes code changes in an isolated way to minimize downstream effects
Promotes consistency at services' boundaries

level3Skills.text: Proactively seeks to inform downstream or dependent teams of proposed code changes
Introduces new code patterns or variations when common code patterns don’t fit the solution
Garners adoption of architectural changes and sees them to completion

Demonstrates knowledge and application of current and new architectural components and when to use them (e.g. lambda architecture, micro service architecture, CQRS, new industry leading products, services)
Introduces simple solutions to meet the customer, business, product and technology needs with available resources and other constraints; avoids over-engineering

Demonstrates knowledge of and articulates solutions for common failure modes in distributed computing, how they occur and how to mitigate them (e.g. thundering herds, partial service degradations, network partitions, queue back pressure, randomized backoff retries, dead-letter queueing)
Responsibly adds features by introducing feature flags or other toggles to enable or disable functionality without requiring code deployments and minimizing negative user impact
Responsibly introduces coupling between codependent features or services (e.g. always assume your downstream service is misbehaving, or is undergoing a deployment, or is otherwise unavailable)
Enables the team to have smooth releases/deployments (e.g. minimizing downtime, having a rollback plan)

level5Skills.text: Evaluates external solutions versus building in-house solutions and provides insightful strategy and recommendations
Acts as a custodian of large architectural or code changes with a philosophy of maintainability, performance and scalability that impacts several systems
Diligently and carefully curates engineering code or infrastructure changes in a way to maximize business impacts across services or teams

Masterfully articulates the trade-offs of using specific patterns vs other approaches and their long term and wholistic impacts to the wider engineering team, product and business (e.g produces detailed and accurate documentation, Incorporates metrics, portrays financial, business and user impacts)
Invents, implements and publishes new system architectures or code patterns that are widely adopted in the organization and or other companies
Governs and makes core engineering wide system architecture decisions while incorporating long term technology goals, industry trends and strategic business objectives

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The process of evaluating software to determine whether or not it satisfies the specified requirements.

level1Skills.text: Code contributions contain reliable and isolated unit tests
Adds test cases to verify bug fixes
Manually tests all changes locally or on the test device before merging
Ensures edge cases are covered in tests
Writes test(s) and test descriptions that serve as a form of documentation
Demonstrates writing the full range of tests, including: unit, integration and system tests
Includes coverage for all applicable platforms and device configurations when writing tests

level3Skills.text: Proactively ensures the performance of the tests suite components (e.g. build, execution and CI/CD) remains adequate
Proactively ensures no flaky (unreliable or non-deterministic) tests are merged. Flags the flaky tests and helps fix them
Utilizes and recommends best testing practices (e.g. writing isolated and well-scoped tests, avoiding sleeping)
Builds out reusable, parameterized test cases
Identifies and closes existing gaps in tests
Prepares training materials, coach and mentors developers about new techniques, ways to write fast, reliable and accurate tests

level5Skills.text: Identifies, recommends and evaluates new testing frameworks with training materials and prototypes
Establishes and promotes a testing first culture to help improve the overall quality and reliability of our products release over release
Advocates for innovative testing practices and influences developer community to adopt new methods through presentations, blog posts, training sessions and conference talks
Wrote or heavily contributed to a testing frameworks

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The practice of identifying and diagnosing issues with software, ranging from bugs to performance issues.

level1Skills.text: Adds meaningful log messages and follows existing logging standards
Adds meaningful metrics, traces, and other telemetry using existing standards that can be utilized later in alarms and dashboards
Leverages exception monitoring tools (like Bugsnag or Crashlytics) to fix bugs
Comfortable with, and reaches for, debuggers and print-debugging to diagnose issues

Familiar with, and uses when necessary, other debugging tools like view debuggers (i.e. Android Hierarchy Viewer, Reveal), debugging proxies (i.e. Charles Proxy), HTML inspectors (i.e. Chrome DevTools), runtime introspection tools (i.e. Erlang observer, Recon), etc.

level3Skills.text: Implements load tests, performance tests, stress tests and/or benchmarks to validate the performance of the system
Proficient with, and reaches for, code profiling tools (i.e. Instruments, Android Profiler) to diagnose performance issues
Shares performance results and analysis with the immediate team to improve everyone’s understanding of the system
Proactively identifies performance problems (e.g. missing database indexes, unnecessary queries/API calls, underperforming code, heavily contested locks) and works with the team to address them
Diagnoses issues that span multiple components (e.g. frontend, backend, infrastructure)

level5Skills.text: Evangelizes to developers about new debugging and profiling techniques or tools, leading to a cultural shift in the organization
Publishes exceptional debugging/profiling related postmortems (à la Cloudflare) to theScore/Interactive tech blog
Evolves debugging and profiling industry-wide by creating/contributing to existing tools/techniques
Inspires wide-reaching improvements to the system by sharing performance results and analysis with the wider engineering organization
Eliminates categories of bugs/performance issues in the organization via shared code, patterns, etc.

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The ability to use tools and techniques to monitor the health of a system. It can be used to ensure the system is meeting expectations and to unlock insights regarding areas of improvement.

level1Skills.text: Creates and updates dashboards for services and flows, using existing tools (e.g. Splunk and Datadog) and adding any interpretation instructions as needed
Uses the most appropriate data sources when building dashboards and alerts
Leverages the appropriate tool and data representation (e.g. charts, type of chart, organizing multiple data points or visualizations) to highlight the most important pieces
Handles on-call incidents in a timely manner, escalating to senior team members and leadership when necessary
Uses existing dashboards and metrics to diagnose system issues during an incident

level3Skills.text: Proactively identifies and addresses monitoring and observability gaps in key application flows
Leads continuous improvements to monitoring and observability across any systems they are familiar with
Creates and maintains runbooks for new and existing features, including: why errors occur, where to look for logs and metrics and how to remediate issues without the need for escalation
Builds dashboards for services and flows, adding any interpretation instructions as needed
Has proven to be reliable with debugging and solutioning complex production incidents
Facilitates proper production incident handling, coordinating the response, consulting with appropriate parties and keeping constant communication with stakeholders
Champions the creation of Service Level Indicators (SLI), Objectives (SLO) and Agreements (SLA) for services according to their respective tier
Champions the improvements necessary to ensure a high signal-to-noise ratio for alerts or other changes that would improve our ability to monitor our systems

level5Skills.text: Leads the organization on evolving its monitoring and observability philosophy and skills (e.g. alerts strategy, how to proactively construct meaningful dashboards and alerts)
Elevates the culture of the organization towards exceptional production incident handling, including follow-up hygiene and future-proof resolutions
Creates or sets monitoring and observability standards that are adopted at other companies and across industries

domainsSkills.domainDescription: The ability to clearly and accurately convey technical information through written, visual or verbal communication.

level1Skills.text: Clearly and concisely documents code changes in Pull Request descriptions, wikis (e.g. Confluence) and code comments
Clearly and concisely outlines changes to workflows and system design
Produces content that is easily understood by other developers
Adds the appropriate amount of context to documentation so it is easily understood by the target audience
Demonstrates an understanding of different types of technical diagrams (e.g. sequence, ERDs, architecture)
Creates and updates technical diagrams

level3Skills.text: Proactively builds technical diagrams to further illustrate code or workflow changes, selecting appropriate diagrams for the concept being communicated
Proactively documents critical system flows and concepts and keeps them up-to-date
Creates complete technical spec documents, including relevant artifacts and cross-functional impacts
Creates and reviews team and organization-wide RFCs
Writes technical blog posts or articles for theScore/Interactive Tech Blog or other medium
Identifies documentation gaps in the organization and champions changes
Clearly and concisely documents and articulates complex technical concepts, changes and technical workflows to both technical and non-technical audiences
Produces written documentation and technical artifacts that are suited for use by external parties such as regulators
Ensures technical documentation is well structured and easily accessible by everyone in the organization

level5Skills.text: Proactively keeps technical documentation organized and consolidated across the organization by identifying opportunities, making and championing changes across the organization and inspiring others to continue this effort

Champions changes in organization-wide technical documentation culture, for example by facilitating training and knowledge sharing opportunities to address documentation skill gaps in the organization and to showcase the positive impact of technical documentation
Is recognized as a prominent author of exceptional technical content in a written medium, commanding an audience (e.g. blog, book, newsletter)
